DataElement.preferredName: Serum Trace Metal Concentration Laboratory Test Result Microgram Per Milliliter Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed._A barely detectable amount._Electropositive chemical elements characterised by ductility, malleability, luster, and conductance of heat and electricity. They can replace the hydrogen of an acid and form bases with hydroxyl radicals._The quantity of a substance per unit volume or weight; a measure of the amount of substance present in a unit amount of mixture, particularly, the amount of solute dissolved in a solvent. The amounts can be expressed as moles, masses, volumes, or parts._A laboratory result using the measure of microgram per milliliter (µg/mL)

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed._A barely detectable amount._Electropositive chemical elements characterised by ductility, malleability, luster, and conductance of heat and electricity. They can replace the hydrogen of an acid and form bases with hydroxyl radicals._The quantity of a substance per unit volume or weight; a measure of the amount of substance present in a unit amount of mixture, particularly, the amount of solute dissolved in a solvent. The amounts can be expressed as moles, masses, volumes, or parts.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

Property.preferredDefinition: A barely detectable amount.:Electropositive chemical elements characterised by ductility, malleability, luster, and conductance of heat and electricity. They can replace the hydrogen of an acid and form bases with hydroxyl radicals.:The quantity of a substance per unit volume or weight; a measure of the amount of substance present in a unit amount of mixture, particularly, the amount of solute dissolved in a solvent. The amounts can be expressed as moles, masses, volumes, or parts.

Concepts.definition: Electropositive chemical elements characterised by ductility, malleability, luster, and conductance of heat and electricity. They can replace the hydrogen of an acid and form bases with hydroxyl radicals.

The quantity of a substance per unit volume or weight; a measure of the amount of substance present in a unit amount of mixture, particularly, the amount of solute dissolved in a solvent. The amounts can be expressed as moles, masses, volumes, or parts.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Laboratory Test Result Microgram Per Milliliter Value
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A laboratory result using the measure of microgram per milliliter (µg/mL)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Laboratory Test Result Microgram Per Milliliter Value
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The outcome of a laboratory test.:A metric unit of mass equal to one millionth of a gram or one thousandth of a milligram.:For each, generally denoting a ratio.:A unit of volume equal to one millionth (10E-6) of a cubic meter, one thousandth of a liter, one cubic centimeter, or 0.061023 7 cubic inch. A cubic centimeter is the CGS unit of volume.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: The outcome of a laboratory test.
A metric unit of mass equal to one millionth of a gram or one thousandth of a milligram.
For each, generally denoting a ratio.
A unit of volume equal to one millionth (10E-6) of a cubic meter, one thousandth of a liter, one cubic centimeter, or 0.061023 7 cubic inch. A cubic centimeter is the CGS unit of volume.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Collect and analyze a blood s
ReferenceDocuments.description: Collect and analyze a blood sample to determine the concentrations of several trace metals. These metals may include cadmium, lead, manganese, selenium, and mercury.
